trans-unit.source: Azure AD .NET Getting Started | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure AD .NET Getting Started | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to build a .NET MVC Web App that integrates with Azure AD for sign in.
trans-unit.target: How to build a .NET MVC Web App that integrates with Azure AD for sign in.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD makes it simple and straightforward to outsource your web app's identity management, providing single sign-in and sign-out with only a few lines of code.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD makes it simple and straightforward to outsource your web app's identity management, providing single sign-in and sign-out with only a few lines of code.

trans-unit.source: In Asp.NET web apps, you can accomplish this using Microsoft's implementation of the community-driven OWIN middleware included in .NET Framework 4.5.
trans-unit.target: In Asp.NET web apps, you can accomplish this using Microsoft's implementation of the community-driven OWIN middleware included in .NET Framework 4.5.

trans-unit.source: Here we'll use OWIN to:
trans-unit.target: Here we'll use OWIN to:

trans-unit.source: Sign the user into the app using Azure AD as the identity provider.
trans-unit.target: Sign the user into the app using Azure AD as the identity provider.

trans-unit.source: Display some information about the user.
trans-unit.target: Display some information about the user.

trans-unit.source: Sign the user out of the app.
trans-unit.target: Sign the user out of the app.

trans-unit.source: In order to do this, you'll need to:
trans-unit.target: In order to do this, you'll need to:

trans-unit.source: Register an application with Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Register an application with Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Set up your app to use the OWIN authentication pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Set up your app to use the OWIN authentication pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Use OWIN to issue sign-in and sign-out requests to Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Use OWIN to issue sign-in and sign-out requests to Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: Print out data about the user.
trans-unit.target: Print out data about the user.

trans-unit.source: To get started, <linkText>download the app skeleton</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>download the completed sample</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To get started, <linkText>download the app skeleton</linkText><title></title> or <linkText>download the completed sample</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need an Azure AD tenant in which to register your application.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need an Azure AD tenant in which to register your application.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have one already, <linkText>learn how to get one</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have one already, <linkText>learn how to get one</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To enable your app to authenticate users, you'll first need to register a new application in your tenant.
trans-unit.target: To enable your app to authenticate users, you'll first need to register a new application in your tenant.

trans-unit.source: Sign into the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign into the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: In the left hand nav, click on Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Select the tenant where you wish to register the application.
trans-unit.target: Select the tenant where you wish to register the application.

trans-unit.source: Click the Applications tab, and click add in the bottom drawer.
trans-unit.target: Click the Applications tab, and click add in the bottom drawer.

trans-unit.source: Follow the prompts and create a new Web Application and/or WebAPI.
trans-unit.target: Follow the prompts and create a new Web Application and/or WebAPI.

trans-unit.source: The name of the application will describe your application to end-users
trans-unit.target: The name of the application will describe your application to end-users

trans-unit.source: The Sign-On URL is the base URL of your app.
trans-unit.target: The Sign-On URL is the base URL of your app.

trans-unit.source: The skeleton's default is https://localhost:44320/.
trans-unit.target: The skeleton's default is https://localhost:44320/.

trans-unit.source: The App ID URI is a unique identifier for your application. The convention is to use https:///, e.g. https://contoso.onmicrosoft.com/my-first-aad-app
trans-unit.target: The App ID URI is a unique identifier for your application. The convention is to use https:///, e.g. https://contoso.onmicrosoft.com/my-first-aad-app

trans-unit.source: Once you've completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique client identifier.
trans-unit.target: Once you've completed registration, AAD will assign your app a unique client identifier.

trans-unit.source: You'll need this value in the next sections, so copy it from the Configure tab.
trans-unit.target: You'll need this value in the next sections, so copy it from the Configure tab.

trans-unit.source: Here, we'll configure the OWIN middleware to use the OpenID Connect authentication protocol.
trans-unit.target: Here, we'll configure the OWIN middleware to use the OpenID Connect authentication protocol.

trans-unit.source: OWIN will be used to issue sign-in and sign-out requests, manage the user's session, and get information about the user, amongst other things.
trans-unit.target: OWIN will be used to issue sign-in and sign-out requests, manage the user's session, and get information about the user, amongst other things.

trans-unit.source: To begin, add the OWIN middleware NuGet packages to the project using the Package Manager Console.
trans-unit.target: To begin, add the OWIN middleware NuGet packages to the project using the Package Manager Console.

trans-unit.source: Add an OWIN Startup class to the project called Startup.cs Right click on the project --> Add --> New Item --> Search for "OWIN".
trans-unit.target: Add an OWIN Startup class to the project called Startup.cs Right click on the project --> Add --> New Item --> Search for "OWIN".

trans-unit.source: The OWIN middleware will invoke the Configuration(...) method when your app starts.
trans-unit.target: The OWIN middleware will invoke the Configuration(...) method when your app starts.

trans-unit.source: Change the class declaration to public partial class Startup - we've already implemented part of this class for you in another file.
trans-unit.target: Change the class declaration to public partial class Startup - we've already implemented part of this class for you in another file.

trans-unit.source: In the Configuration(...) method, make a call to ConfgureAuth(...) to set up authentication for your web app
trans-unit.target: In the Configuration(...) method, make a call to ConfgureAuth(...) to set up authentication for your web app

trans-unit.source: Open the file App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs and implement the ConfigureAuth(...) method.
trans-unit.target: Open the file App_Start\Startup.Auth.cs and implement the ConfigureAuth(...) method.

trans-unit.source: The parameters you provide in OpenIDConnectAuthenticationOptions will serve as coordinates for your app to communicate with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: The parameters you provide in OpenIDConnectAuthenticationOptions will serve as coordinates for your app to communicate with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: You'll also need to set up Cookie Authentication - the OpenID Connect middleware uses cookies underneath the covers.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need to set up Cookie Authentication - the OpenID Connect middleware uses cookies underneath the covers.

trans-unit.source: Finally, open the web.config file in the root of the project, and enter your configuration values in the section.
trans-unit.target: Finally, open the web.config file in the root of the project, and enter your configuration values in the section.

trans-unit.source: Your app's ida:ClientId is the Guid you copied from the Azure Portal in Step 1.
trans-unit.target: Your app's ida:ClientId is the Guid you copied from the Azure Portal in Step 1.

trans-unit.source: The ida:Tenant is the name of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. "contoso.onmicrosoft.com".
trans-unit.target: The ida:Tenant is the name of your Azure AD tenant, e.g. "contoso.onmicrosoft.com".

trans-unit.source: Your ida:PostLogoutRedirectUri indicates to Azure AD where a user should be redirected after a sign-out request successfully completes.
trans-unit.target: Your ida:PostLogoutRedirectUri indicates to Azure AD where a user should be redirected after a sign-out request successfully completes.

trans-unit.source: Your app is now properly configured to communicate with Azure AD using the OpenID Connect authentication protocol.
trans-unit.target: Your app is now properly configured to communicate with Azure AD using the OpenID Connect authentication protocol.

trans-unit.source: OWIN has taken care of all of the ugly details of crafting authentication messages, validating tokens from Azure AD, and maintaining user session.
trans-unit.target: OWIN has taken care of all of the ugly details of crafting authentication messages, validating tokens from Azure AD, and maintaining user session.

trans-unit.source: All that remains is to give your users a way to sign in and sign out.
trans-unit.target: All that remains is to give your users a way to sign in and sign out.

trans-unit.source: You can use authorize tags in your controllers to require that user signs in before accessing a certain page.
trans-unit.target: You can use authorize tags in your controllers to require that user signs in before accessing a certain page.

trans-unit.source: Open Controllers\HomeController.cs, and add the [Authorize] tag to the About controller.
trans-unit.target: Open Controllers\HomeController.cs, and add the [Authorize] tag to the About controller.

trans-unit.source: You can also use OWIN to directly issue authentication requests from within your code.
trans-unit.target: You can also use OWIN to directly issue authentication requests from within your code.

trans-unit.source: Open Controllers\AccountController.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open Controllers\AccountController.cs.

trans-unit.source: In the SignIn() and SignOut() actions, issue OpenID Connect challenge and sign-out requests, respectively.
trans-unit.target: In the SignIn() and SignOut() actions, issue OpenID Connect challenge and sign-out requests, respectively.

trans-unit.source: Now, open Views\Shared\_LoginPartial.cshtml.
trans-unit.target: Now, open Views\Shared\_LoginPartial.cshtml.

trans-unit.source: This is where you'll show the user your app's sign-in and sign-out links, and print out the user's name in a view.
trans-unit.target: This is where you'll show the user your app's sign-in and sign-out links, and print out the user's name in a view.

trans-unit.source: When authenticating users with OpenID Connect, Azure AD returns an id_token to the application that contains "claims," or assertions about the user.
trans-unit.target: When authenticating users with OpenID Connect, Azure AD returns an id_token to the application that contains "claims," or assertions about the user.

trans-unit.source: You can use these claims to personalize your app:
trans-unit.target: You can use these claims to personalize your app:

trans-unit.source: Open the Controllers\HomeController.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Open the Controllers\HomeController.cs file.

trans-unit.source: You can access the user's claims in your controllers via the ClaimsPrincipal.Current security principal object.
trans-unit.target: You can access the user's claims in your controllers via the ClaimsPrincipal.Current security principal object.

trans-unit.source: Finally, build and run your app!
trans-unit.target: Finally, build and run your app!

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already, now is the time to create a new user in your tenant with a *.onmicrosoft.com domain.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already, now is the time to create a new user in your tenant with a *.onmicrosoft.com domain.

trans-unit.source: Sign in with that user, and notice how the user's identity is reflected in the top navigation bar.
trans-unit.target: Sign in with that user, and notice how the user's identity is reflected in the top navigation bar.

trans-unit.source: Sign out, and sign back in as another user in your tenant.
trans-unit.target: Sign out, and sign back in as another user in your tenant.

trans-unit.source: If you're feeling particularly ambitious, register and run another instance of this application (with its own clientId), and watch see single-sign on in action.
trans-unit.target: If you're feeling particularly ambitious, register and run another instance of this application (with its own clientId), and watch see single-sign on in action.

trans-unit.source: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) <linkText>is provided here</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For reference, the completed sample (without your configuration values) <linkText>is provided here</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You can now move onto more advanced topics.
trans-unit.target: You can now move onto more advanced topics.

trans-unit.source: You may want to try:
trans-unit.target: You may want to try:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Secure a Web API with Azure AD >></linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Secure a Web API with Azure AD >></linkText><title></title>
